claim: One in 10,000 people have a completely photographic memory.

supporting.text: Scientific studies on memory consistently show that true photographic memory, where individuals can recall images with perfect accuracy, is extremely rare and not well-documented in the general population.

attacks.text: Scientific studies on memory consistently show that true photographic memory, where individuals can recall images with perfect accuracy, is extremely rare and not well-documented in the general population.
Some individuals with hyperthymesia or savant syndrome exhibit memory capabilities that closely resemble photographic memory, suggesting it may exist in rare cases.
Hyperthymesia and savant syndrome are distinct from photographic memory, as they often involve exceptional recall of personal experiences or specific domains rather than perfect visual recall.
Anecdotal reports and media portrayals often exaggerate memory abilities, leading to the misconception that photographic memory is more common than it is.
Scientific rigor in memory studies often excludes anecdotal evidence, which may overlook genuine cases of exceptional memory due to lack of documentation.

supporting.text: Cognitive psychology research indicates that most claims of photographic memory are exaggerated or refer to highly trained memory skills rather than innate, perfect recall.

attacks.text: Cognitive psychology research indicates that most claims of photographic memory are exaggerated or refer to highly trained memory skills rather than innate, perfect recall.
Some documented cases, such as Solomon Shereshevsky, demonstrate individuals with extraordinary recall abilities that closely resemble photographic memory.
Shereshevsky's abilities were highly unusual and may have been linked to synesthesia rather than pure photographic memory, making his case an exception.
The term 'photographic memory' is often misused in popular media, leading to inflated public perception of its prevalence.
Scientific studies on eidetic memory in children suggest that some forms of near-perfect recall exist, though they are rare and often fade with age.

supporting.text: Neurological evidence does not support the existence of a completely photographic memory as a widespread or measurable phenomenon in humans.

attacks.text: Neurological evidence does not support the existence of a completely photographic memory as a widespread or measurable phenomenon in humans.
Some rare case studies, such as Solomon Shereshevsky, demonstrate individuals with near-photographic memory abilities.
Shereshevsky's abilities were exceptional and not representative of general human memory capabilities, reinforcing the rarity of photographic memory.
The lack of neurological evidence may be due to insufficient research or detection methods, not the absence of the phenomenon.
Current neuroimaging techniques are highly advanced and would likely detect such a distinctive memory mechanism if it were widespread.

supporting.text: Memory experts and neuroscientists generally agree that the concept of photographic memory is a myth, with no verified cases meeting the strict definition of perfect recall.

attacks.text: Memory experts and neuroscientists generally agree that the concept of photographic memory is a myth, with no verified cases meeting the strict definition of perfect recall.
Some documented cases, like Solomon Shereshevsky, demonstrate recall abilities so exceptional they are functionally indistinguishable from photographic memory.
Shereshevsky's abilities were linked to synesthesia and mnemonic techniques, not true photographic memory as defined by instant, perfect recall without effort.
The 1-in-10,000 claim may refer to highly superior autobiographical memory (HSAM), which involves extraordinary recall of personal experiences but not universal perfect memory.
HSAM individuals still make errors and show selectivity in recall, failing to meet the strict definition of photographic memory.

supporting.text: Population studies on memory capabilities have not identified a consistent subgroup representing 1 in 10,000 individuals with photographic memory.

attacks.text: Population studies on memory capabilities have not identified a consistent subgroup representing 1 in 10,000 individuals with photographic memory.
Anecdotal evidence and case studies suggest rare individuals exhibit memory capabilities consistent with photographic memory, even if large-scale studies have not confirmed the exact prevalence.
Anecdotal evidence lacks scientific rigor and may be influenced by confirmation bias or subjective interpretation of memory abilities.
Some cognitive research identifies exceptional memory performers, though they may not meet the strict definition of photographic memory, supporting the plausibility of the claim.
Exceptional memory performers often rely on mnemonic techniques rather than true photographic memory, which is a distinct and unverified phenomenon.
